statement.text: An interposition graft replaces a diseased or damaged arterial segment with a conduit (vein or prosthetic) connected end-to-end, maintaining inline arterial flow and used when the defect is too long for primary repair.

explanation.intuition: When a segment of artery is damaged or diseased and can't be fixed directly, you cut out the bad part and sew in a replacement piece - like splicing in a new section of pipe.
explanation.key_insight: Interposition grafts are inline reconstructions requiring two end-to-end anastomoses. They're ideal when native vessel alignment is preserved. Vein is preferred for peripheral arteries; prosthetic is acceptable for large vessels.
explanation.technical_details: Indications: trauma with >2cm defect, aneurysm, infected pseudoaneurysm, iatrogenic injury. Conduit selection: autogenous vein (preferred for small/medium arteries), prosthetic (acceptable for aorta, iliac, femoral). Technique: resect diseased segment, measure defect, harvest appropriate length conduit, proximal then distal end-to-end anastomosis. Orientation: reversed vein or in situ for matched diameter. Tension: conduit slightly longer than defect to avoid tension.

conduit_selection.vein: Preferred for peripheral arteries (popliteal, brachial, femoral)
conduit_selection.prosthetic: Acceptable for aorta, iliac; consider PTFE with heparin bonding

technique_tips: Cut conduit slightly longer to avoid tension
Proximal anastomosis first for bleeding control

clinical_pearls: Vein is preferred conduit for peripheral interposition grafts
Cut conduit slightly longer than defect to avoid anastomotic tension
Useful for trauma when primary repair would narrow the vessel
